questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams.
You need to identify which teams were inactive during the past 90 days.
What should you use?

discussion.content: Teams usage report only shows "active" teams, not "inactive"

Selected Answer: C
The answer is correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams.
Users report poor call quality.
You need to identify whether Teams calls use TCP or UDP.
What should you review in the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard?

discussion.content: I think the answer is D, you can see TCP vs UDP usage on the right hand column in Quality of Experience, don't see anything like that in Quality Drill down section.

comments.content: D looks correct to find it -->Quality of Experience--> Audio Quality-- Conference--> HTTP Proxy Usage--> TCP Usage

discussion.content: from here to the Moon it is :D Quality of Experience

Selected Answer: D
To identify whether Teams calls are using TCP or UDP in the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, you should review the Quality of Experience Reports (option D). These reports provide detailed information on the quality of voice and video calls, including the network route used, packet loss, delay, and other metrics that can affect call quality. In these reports, you can identify whether calls are using UDP or TCP.

Selected Answer: D
Correct answer is D .
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/quality-of-experience-review-guide
(D) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/quality-of-experience-review-guide

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

Selected Answer: D
Should be D, QoER shows:"Audio quality and reliability for all clients and devices, including meeting rooms. These reports are a "slimmed-down" version of the downloadable CQD templates, focusing on key areas for analyzing audio quality and reliability."

Selected Answer: D
correct answer is D
The correct answer is Quality of Experience Reports. Checked and confirmed.

Selected Answer: D
correct answer is D
D. Quality of Experience Reports
Los informes de uso no proporcionan ese dato que preguntan,

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

Your company has 10 offices in North America and Europe.

The company has 5,000 users.

You plan to deploy Microsoft Teams for all the users.

You run a pilot project for the planned deployment.

You need to identify the network packet loss from the pilot computers to Microsoft Teams during calls.

Solution: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, you review Usage reports.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Although the Network testing companion can be used to measure packet loss, it is for individual computer use. it would be cumbersome to need to install this on every computer that will be testing.
The call quality dashboard on the other hand, can generate reports on the call quality for all pilot computers, and would likely be the Microsoft preferred answer.
Will go with B if seen on exam.

I would say B as the Network Testing Companion is something I would run to test the environment/endpoints before rolling out Teams. CQD would be the go to after the deployment to determine Packet Loss
On Test 18.01.22

B is correct (i think) - this tool does help, but has to installed on individual machines using local admin privileges. A pilot deployment will consist of more than one user and will require a lot resource to deploy this tool on each computer. If the question stated for "one user" then you could use the tool.
B is correct
Again durring calls, Network Testing Companion is not realtime, but a testing moment
If this question appears in the exam, I will choose B. The Network Testing Companion is less detailed and it is not focused on the daily operations.

comments.content: Network Testing Companion is suitable for testing network environment prior piloting but not the right tool for identify packet loss during meeting/call.

It does have a packet loss metric in it 
https://www.uc.solutions/Microsoft_Teams/Microsoft_Teams_Technical_Info/Teams_Network_Testing_Companion

discussion.content:
A is correct you can identify Packet lost or blocked port in
Network Testing Companion->Start Tests->View Results->Network quality/Network connectivity
And it can be used for Skype for business as well for Teams

comments.content: Yep - All my research leads to this "B" being the answer

discussion.content: Sorry but the tool is for SfB Teams users Network Planner so answer is B
A should be correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams.

Users report poor call quality.

You need to identify the source of the call quality issues and which locations are affected.

What should you do first?

choices.B: Upload building data to the Call quality dashboard.
choices.A: Run the Teams user activity report.
choices.D: Upload reporting labels for each location.
choices.C: Run the Teams device usage report.
